page.title: 17Greenhill Lodge Farm (cont)
page.content: The fields of the farm had all been sown with grass and were intensivly managed.Apart from sheep and cows, Mr. Bower kept a few hens to provide eggs for the use of his family.He had no pigs. The farm which was yellow brick was probably built in the 1830's or 1840's.Its roof was made of{Rosemary {tiles}and the windows were sash windows.The cowsheds and other outbuildings were built round an enclosed paved yard.An interesting feature was a dove cote with nine pigeon holes set high in the roof of one of the buildings.When Mr.Bower first took over the farm there were over one hundred nesting boxes there. Pigeon pie used to be very popular with the previous farmers there,who fed the pigeons to provide extra meat. Only six now remain.
